## Natural history notes

The Common Axil-Flower (Mecardonia acuminata) is a small, creeping wildflower native to moist sandy soils, ditches, and open wetlands across the southeastern United States. It produces bright yellow, tubular flowers nestled in the leaf axils, giving the plant its common name. Blooming from spring through fall, it attracts small bees and other pollinators. Its low, spreading growth helps stabilize soil and adds subtle color to wetland edges and damp meadows.
